conversations.content: What motivated you to create Hacker News, and what did you initially envision it to be?

I started Hacker News as a side project, mainly to test out Arc, our new programming language. I wanted a real-world application to sharpen the language, and a news site seemed like a good fit. Plus, I figured it'd be a nice hub for our Y Combinator founder community to swap articles and discuss startup-related issues. I didn't expect it to take off like it did, but I'm glad it has.
What drives the author to encourage examination of the lies told to children, and what do they hope to achieve by doing so?

it's fascinating to me that we just accept that lying to kids is just a normal part of life, like brushing your teeth or eating veggies. But think about it - these lies can have lasting effects on us. I mean, how many of us still remember being told that Santa Claus is real, only to find out later it was a fabrication? It's like, what's the purpose of that? Is it to protect our innocence or to make our parents' lives easier? So, I want to take a closer look at why we tell these lies, and what benefits or drawbacks they bring. Maybe by doing so, we can refine our approach and create a more honest, open dialogue with our kids.
What inspired you to use a toddler as a metaphor to describe the early stages of a startup?

The toddler thing? Yeah, that just came from observing how both my own kids and startups operate. They're both in this phase of intense experimentation, where they're trying to figure out the world and their place in it. They stumble, they fall, but they always get back up and keep moving forward. And just like how you can't really blame a toddler for knocking over a vase, you can't blame a startup for making mistakes - it's all part of the learning process. It's just the nature of the beast.
What motivated you to search for a general term to describe iPhones, iPads, and Android devices?

it's one of those things that's been bugging me for a while. I just got tired of having to say "iPhone, iPad, or Android device" every time I wanted to refer to those things in conversation. It's just cumbersome, you know? And "mobile devices" doesn't quite cut it, as I said. I mean, that's like calling a Porsche a "vehicle" - it's technically true, but it doesn't really do it justice. I wanted a word that captures the essence of what makes those devices special - the way they're always connected, the way they've changed how we interact with information... the whole shebang.
What inspired the author to use the concept of "schlep blindness" to describe the phenomenon of overlooking great startup ideas?

I think I was just trying to put my finger on this weird phenomenon where people overlook these great startup ideas right under their noses. And I was talking to some friends who are entrepreneurs, and we were all just kind of commiserating about how we all have this habit of not seeing the obvious opportunities. And one of them mentioned this Yiddish word "schlep", which basically means a tedious, annoying task. And I thought, "Aha! That's it!" - we're not seeing these great ideas because they're hiding in plain sight, but we're blinded by the schlep of doing them. It's like we're allergic to the effort required to turn them into realities. And that's how "schlep blindness" was born.
What motivated the author to correct the misconception about Y Combinator being a "one-man show"?

The gross simplification of Y Combinator's history gets my goat. I mean, I've seen it written that it was just Paul Graham running the show solo, and that's just not how it was. The thing is, Jessica Livingston was an integral part of YC from the get-go, and to gloss over that is to misrepresent the very fabric of the organization. It's not just about fairness, although that's part of it; it's about accuracy.
What motivates the author to associate a lack of charisma with being disliked, particularly in the context of powerful individuals?

You see, I've always been fascinated by the way people respond to those in power. And what I've found is that when someone's got the goods, but can't win people over with their charm, they're like a big ol' bullseye for criticism. People can smell the power, but if they can't connect with the person wielding it, they'll turn on 'em. It's like, our natural reaction is to distrust the powerful, but if they can charm us, we give 'em a pass. But without that charm, man, you're just a target. And I think that's exactly what happened with Hillary Clinton - she had the brains, the experience, the whole nine yards, but she just didn't have that certain je ne sais quoi that makes people like you. Same with those CEOs - if they're all about getting the job done but can't work a room, people are gonna be skeptical.
What motivates the author to pursue insights that are both general and surprising, despite the difficulty in achieving this combination?

You see, I think it's precisely because that territory tends to be picked clean that I'm drawn to it. It's the thrill of the hunt, the challenge of uncovering something that's both profound and unexpected. And let's be honest, there's a certain satisfaction in knowing that I'm not just regurgitating the same old ideas that everyone else has already hashed out. I mean, who wants to simply reiterate the obvious? The real thrill comes from stumbling upon an insight that's both general and surprising - it's like striking gold, you know? So, despite the difficulty, I'm willing to take on the challenge because the payoff is just too great.
What role do you believe personal experience plays in shaping one's perspective on social and cultural changes?

"Personal experience, I think, is essential in shaping our perspective on social and cultural changes. I mean, I'm not just talking about seeing change happen, I'm talking about living it. I've witnessed the fragmentation of US politics, I've seen the creative class cluster in a few favored cities, I've felt the cultural common ground slipping away. And you know what? That's what gives me the right to comment on it. I'm not just theorizing, I'm not just reading about it in a book, I'm living it. And I think that's what's missing from a lot of the discourse these days - people actually experiencing the changes, and then speaking from that place of authority. Not just pontificating, but actually seeing it, feeling it, and then talking about it."
What motivated you to take a snapshot of Viaweb's site just hours before the Yahoo acquisition was announced in June 1998?
I thought it might be interesting to look at one day.
What motivated you to highlight "Determination" as the first quality you look for in startup founders?

I think it's because determination is the most important quality in getting a startup off the ground. So many things go wrong, and you need someone who's just going to push through all that. I mean, everyone knows startups are hard, but until you've done it, you don't realize just how hard. You're constantly facing obstacles, and you need someone who's just going to persevere. And I think that's what separates the successful startups from the ones that fizzle out.
What inspired you to view a recession as an opportunity to start a startup, rather than a hindrance?

I think people have this knee-jerk reaction to recessions, like, oh no, the sky is falling! But if you look back at history, some of the most iconic companies were founded during downturns. I mean, Microsoft and Apple, like I mentioned in the essay, those guys didn't let a little thing like a recession hold them back. And why should they? When everyone else is running for cover, that's when the brave and the clever can make their move. It's like the whole world is on sale, and the entrepreneurs who can see past the doom and gloom are the ones who are going to come out on top.
What inspired you to choose "Make something people want" as Y Combinator's motto, and how has your understanding of this phrase evolved over time?

it was pretty straightforward, really. We were just trying to figure out what advice to give to the startups we were funding. And we realized that the most important thing was to make something people actually wanted. It sounds obvious, but it's surprising how many people don't get it. They focus on the technology, or the business model, or the exit strategy, and they forget that the only thing that really matters is whether people want what they're making. I mean, think about it: if you make something people want, you're probably going to be okay. If you don't, you're probably not. So, it was really just a distillation of what we thought was the most important thing for a startup to focus on. 

Now, over time, I think our understanding of what that phrase means has evolved. I think we've gotten a better sense of just how hard it is to make something people want. I mean, it's really, really hard. It requires a deep understanding of your users, and a willingness to adapt and change and iterate. It's not just about building some cool technology or making something that you think is neat. It's about making something that solves a real problem for people. And that's a much taller order than it sounds.
What principle did you learn from Paul Buchheit that guides your advice to startups?
that it's better to make a few people really happy than to make a lot of people semi-happy.
What inspired David Heinemeier Hansson to advocate for taking an old-fashioned approach to startup success?

DH's talk at Startup School really came from his own experiences as the creator of Ruby on Rails. He's always been a bit of a rebel, and I think he's just tired of the whole "get-rich-quick" mentality that pervades the startup world. He wants people to focus on building real value, creating something that actually matters, rather than just chasing a quick exit.
What inspired you to create a personal list of heroes, and what criteria did you use to select the individuals who made the cut?

it's funny - I've always thought that hero is a weird word. It's like, what does it even mean, really? But I realized that, for me, heroes are just people who, for whatever reason, make me want to be a better person. And I don't mean that in some cheesy, inspirational poster kind of way. I just mean that when I think about these people, I want to be more like them - not because they're perfect or because I want to emulate every single thing they do, but because they've all got this... this spark, you know? This thing that makes me want to be more thoughtful, more curious, more honest. So, I didn't really use some kind of scientific criteria to select them. It's more like... I just knew. I knew that these were the people who, in some way or another, have changed me for the better.
What changed the author's initial perspective on patents, and when did this shift occur?

I used to think patents were all about protecting inventors, and that was that. But then I started noticing how they were being used to stifle innovation, to create these ridiculous lawsuits and stifling competition. It was like, wait a minute, this isn't helping progress, it's hindering it. And I think that's when it clicked for me, in August 2011. I realized we couldn't just sit around waiting for the government to fix this mess, we had to take action ourselves.
What inspired you to describe Silicon Valley as "suburban sprawl" with "no conspicuous monuments," and what do you hope to convey about the area's character?

I wanted to dispel this myth that Silicon Valley is some glamorous, shiny place. It's not. It's a bunch of low-slung buildings and strip malls. I mean, it's not like New York City or Paris, where you've got iconic landmarks everywhere. No, Silicon Valley is basically just a bunch of office parks and highways. And that's what I'm getting at with "suburban sprawl" - it's not exactly a hub of architectural innovation. But, paradoxically, that's exactly what makes it so great. There's a humility to the place, a lack of pretension, that lets you focus on the real innovation happening behind those unassuming facades.
How does the author believe one can avoid working on overly obvious ideas and instead stumble upon something new and innovative?

"Yeah, you gotta work on the stuff that's good but not obvious, you know? If an idea is clearly a winner, chances are someone else is already all over it. You gotta take some risk, venture into the unknown, and that's where the real innovation happens. It's like, you're not gonna stumble upon anything new and exciting if you're just going down the same old paths everyone else is on."
What motivated you to question the notion that "life is short" and ponder its relativity to our lifespan?

You see, I think it's because I was always fascinated by the way we humans have this tendency to whine about the brevity of life, without ever stopping to consider whether it's actually the length of life that's the problem, or if it's just our own perception of it. I mean, think about it - if we lived to be, say, 500 years old, would we still be complaining about how short life is? Would we still be making the same clichéd remarks about how fast time flies? It's almost as if we're more concerned with the idea of life being short, rather than the actual reality of it. So, I just wanted to poke a little hole in that notion, and explore it in a more...let's say, existential way.
What inspired you to reflect on your own potential regrets and how did that influence your interpretation of Bronnie Ware's list?

I think it's just this creeping sense of mortality, you know? I mean, we're all just sort of sleepwalking through life, and then suddenly you're faced with this list of regrets from people who are, staring death in the face. It's like, what are we doing with our time, right? And then I started thinking, okay, what would I regret if I were in their shoes? That's when it hit me - I could see myself making the same mistakes. It was like, this punch to the gut, you know? So, I started thinking about what it means to not make those mistakes, and that's when the "don't be a cog" thing really crystallized for me.
What motivates you more, improving your communication skills or having meaningful ideas to convey?

What I'm getting at is, it's not about being a smooth talker or a silver-tongued devil; it's about having something worthwhile to say in the first place. Give me a good idea any day over being able to reel off a bunch of empty words.

What motivated you to explore the topic of economic inequality, and what personal connection do you have to it?

"I was motivated to explore the topic of economic inequality because I was one of the founders... of something, which I won't bother specifying here. Let's just say it's given me a certain perspective on the issue. Anyway, that's how I got interested in this question."
What motivated you to risk damaging your reputation with a particular group of people in order to make a point about the importance of obsessive interest in achieving greatness?

You want to know why I was willing to take a flamethrower to my reputation with certain folks, right? Well, let me tell you, it's because I've seen too many people waste their potential by not being honest about what it takes to achieve greatness. They want to believe that just being smart and working hard is enough, but it's not. I've been in the trenches, I've seen the difference that obsessive interest makes, and I'm willing to ruffle some feathers to drive that point home. Plus, let's be real, if I'm going to be remembered for anything, it might as well be for telling the uncomfortable truth.
What inspired you to write about the changes in the startup funding business, and what message did you hope to convey to aspiring entrepreneurs?

I just got tired of seeing the same old same old in the startup funding space. I mean, it had been stagnant for decades, and suddenly, everything's changing. And I'm not just talking about the money, I'm talking about the whole landscape. I wanted to give the lowdown to all the aspiring entrepreneurs out there, to let them know that the rules have changed. And I'm not just talking about the funding environment, I'm talking about the whole startup ecosystem. It's like, if you want to start a startup, you gotta understand what's going on, you know? And that's what I wanted to convey - that this is a whole new ball game, and if you're not paying attention, you're gonna get left behind. So, that's what inspired me to write this essay, to give people a wake-up call, to tell them that the times, they are a-changin', and if you wanna succeed, you gotta adapt, you know?
What inspired you to investigate the disparity in startup success rates across different cities?

it's just something that's always bugged me. I mean, why is it that you've got these pockets of innovation and entrepreneurship in some places, and then it's like a desert in others? It's not like it's a secret or anything, but nobody ever really talks about it. I just got tired of accepting it as a given, you know? It's like, what's the deal, right? Is it the water? Is it the vibe? Is it something in the air? I just wanted to dig in and try to figure out what's going on.
What inspired the author to discuss the relationship between startup acquisitions and innovation?

I was just sitting there, thinking about why we don't see more behemoths like Google emerging from the startup scene, and then I stumble upon Umair Haque's piece. He's the one who really nailed it - most startups get snatched up before they can reach their full potential. That got me thinking, what if these startups were given the chance to grow, to innovate, to change the world? It's not just about a quick exit, it's about creating something that truly makes a dent.
What motivates the author to emphasize the importance of creating something people want in a startup?

Because I've seen too many startups keel over and die because they were solving a problem that nobody actually had. And that's just such a waste. All that work, all that talent, down the drain. It's like, guys, if you're gonna bother to start a company, can't you at least make something that someone, anyone, actually wants? It's not that hard, right? Just make something people want. That's it. But no, instead, I see people chasing after some flashy idea or trying to be the next big thing, without stopping to think, "Wait, does anyone actually need this?" And then they wonder why they can't get traction, why nobody cares. It's because nobody cares! You gotta make something people want. That's the secret sauce, folks.
What motivated you to write this essay, despite anticipating that your views might be considered controversial?

I've always found it rather peculiar that people tend to shy away from speaking their minds simply because it may ruffle a few feathers. I've never been one to mince words or sugarcoat the truth, even if it means going against the grain. I wrote this essay because I believed - and still do - that someone needs to cut through the nonsense and offer a dose of reality. The fact that my views might be considered "controversial" only strengthened my resolve to speak out. In an age where people are more interested in hearing what they want to hear rather than what they need to hear, I figure it's high time someone shook things up a bit.
What motivated you to write this essay, and what did you hope to achieve through this introspective exercise?

Annoyance. That's what motivated me, plain and simple. I was tired of seeing Y Combinator misrepresented, watered down, or just plain misunderstood. We'd been at it for three years, and yet people were still getting it wrong. So, I figured, why not take a step back, and really try to articulate what we're about? It wasn't just about setting the record straight, though that was part of it. I wanted to understand it myself, to distill the essence of Y Combinator, to figure out what makes us tick. Plus, it was a chance for me to take a break from the daily grind, reflect on what we'd accomplished, and think about what it all means. I hoped to achieve a deeper understanding, not just for others, but for myself, of what we're trying to do here.
What inspired you to highlight the intimidating nature of ambitious startup ideas in this essay?

I've just seen so many would-be founders get cold feet when they come across an idea that's truly massive in scope. They're drawn to it, but they're also terrified of failing on such a grand scale. And I think that's a shame, because those are often the ideas that could change the world. I wanted to highlight this phenomenon because I think it's a crucial hurdle for entrepreneurs to overcome. By exposing these fears, I hope to embolden readers to take on the kinds of projects that could truly leave a mark on history.
What motivated you to identify the disconnect between VCs and startups as an "unexploited opportunity" in startup funding?

"I've always been fascinated by the way the VC model can sometimes feel like a square peg trying to fit into a round hole. It's like, these VCs are set up to write big checks, but there are all these startups out there that just need a smaller amount of cash to get off the ground. It's like they're operating on different wavelengths, you know? And that's when it hit me - this isn't a problem, it's an opportunity! Someone's gotta fill that gap. And that someone might just be Y Combinator."
What motivated you to emphasize the importance of initial funding for startups, highlighting Y Combinator's role in the process?

I think it's just brutal honesty, really. I mean, most startups aren't just going to hit it big with one shot of funding. That's not how it works. It's a process, and it's iterative. You need that initial push, that kickstart, and that's where Y Combinator comes in - as a catalyst, really. They're not just writing checks, they're providing a network, a community, and a sense of legitimacy. And let's be real, when you're just starting out, you need all the help you can get. So, I emphasized the importance of initial funding because, frankly, it's a crucial step in getting your startup off the ground. Without it, you're just treading water.
What triggers the author to observe patterns in various fields, leading them to conclude that only a small fraction of possibilities have been explored?

You want to know what sparked this realization in me? It's because I've been fortunate enough to have had a somewhat unconventional career path, allowing me to dabble in multiple fields. I've seen the same dynamics play out in each one – a flurry of activity, but all of it clustered around a few popular ideas. It was only when I stepped back, looked at the larger landscape, that I noticed how much uncharted territory lay untouched. Suddenly, the same patterns began to emerge everywhere I looked. It was as if I'd stumbled into a hidden truth: despite the impressive collective effort, we've barely scratched the surface of what's possible.
What motivates the author to emphasize the importance of writing in spoken language, and what do they believe happens to people when they start writing?

You want to know what gets my goat about writing, right? Well, let me tell you - it's how people suddenly transform into a stuffy, pompous version of themselves the moment they put pen to paper. It's like they think they need to sound "writerly" or something. Newsflash: nobody talks like that in real life! And that's exactly why I'm so big on writing in spoken language. When you write like you talk, people can relate, they can listen, they can get it. But when you start using "writer words" and convoluted sentences, you might as well be speaking Swahili. People's eyes glaze over, and you've lost 'em. So, yeah, that's what's behind my "trick" for getting people to read what you write: just talk to 'em, already!
What inspired the author to explore the possibility of detecting bias in a selection process without knowing the applicant pool?

I've always been fascinated by the subtle ways bias can creep into our decision-making processes, even when we think we're being objective. And I started wondering, what if we could sniff out bias without needing to know all the nitty-gritty details about the applicants themselves? It was one of those "what if" moments that got me digging deeper, and eventually led me to explore this intriguing possibility.
What distinguishes intentional moderates from accidental moderates in the author's perspective?

You see, the intentional moderates, they're the trimmers, deliberately choosing to occupy the middle ground, calculating their stance to avoid alienating either side. It's a conscious decision, a deliberate choice to plant their flag firmly in the center. On the other hand, accidental moderates stumble into the middle, more by virtue of their own inconsistent or disjointed views than any deliberate attempt to occupy the center. One is a deliberate strategy, the other a happenstance. That's the distinction I'm making.
What inspired the author to write this essay, specifically targeting college students, and what message did they intend to convey to this demographic?

"Look, I wrote this essay because I wanted to tell college students the truth about startups. Most of them are sitting in class thinking, 'Oh, I'm gonna change the world with my amazing idea,' but they have no clue what it takes to actually make it happen. I wanted to slap them in the face, wake them up, and say, 'Hey, it's not just about having a great idea, it's about execution, it's about grinding, it's about being willing to learn and adapt.' I also wanted to give them a boot in the right direction, to steer them towards the resources that can help them, like Y Combinator. I mean, if I can save one kid from wasting his time on some half-baked idea, then I've done my job. So, to all the college students out there, I'm saying, 'Listen up, this is the real deal, and if you're not ready to put in the work, then you might as well pack it up and go get a job at Google.'"
What led you to connect the dots between the addictiveness of various substances and the accelerating process that creates them?

I've always been fascinated by the way we, as a society, tend to enable and even encourage addictive behaviors. Like, think about it - we're constantly chasing that next high, whether it's a substance or a new gadget or whatever. And I started noticing this pattern where these substances, these addictive things, they're all more concentrated forms of something that came before. I mean, crack is just a more potent version of cocaine, right? And cocaine is just a more potent version of coca leaves. And it got me thinking, what's driving this process? Why are we so hell-bent on creating these more and more addictive things? And that's when it hit me - it's not just about the things themselves, it's about the system that creates them. It's about this accelerating process that's driving us towards more and more intense, more and more addictive experiences. And that's what really scared me, you know? Because if we don't stop and take a hard look at what's going on here, we might just create something that we can't escape.
What inspired you to investigate the communication patterns of unsuccessful startups, and what did you hope to achieve by doing so?

It was this gut feeling I had, you know? Like, I'd be talking to these founders, and it was like they just weren't getting it. And I'm not just talking about not getting my advice, I mean, not getting the whole concept of a startup. So I started thinking, "Wait a minute, what's going on here?" And that's when I started to notice this weird correlation between the ones that were struggling and how hard it was to have a conversation with them. It was like they were speaking a different language or something. And I'm like, "What if that's not a coincidence?" What if the reason they're struggling is because they can't communicate? And that's when I decided to dig deeper, to see if I could find some answers. I hoped to achieve some kind of insight, you know? Like, what's the deal with these founders? Are they just not cut out for this? Or is there something else going on?
What motivated you to reflect on the "nastiness" in hacker culture, and what do you think is the root cause of trolls' behavior?

I think it's because I've always been fascinated by this contradictory thing about hacker culture - on the one hand, it's all about creating and building and pushing the boundaries of what's possible, and on the other hand, there's this undercurrent of hostility and aggression that can be really alienating. And I think that comment on Hacker News just brought it all to the surface for me, you know? It made me realize that I wasn't the only one who'd noticed this weird tension between the ideals of the hacker ethos and the way some people actually behave online. As for the root cause of trolls, I think it's because they're often just trying to assert some kind of dominance or control over others - they're not really interested in having a genuine conversation or exchange of ideas, they just want to stir up drama and get a reaction. It's like they're addicted to the rush of adrenaline they get from pushing people's buttons.
What motivated you to argue that the importance of economies of scale is diminishing?

You see, I think what's happening is that this old model, this assumption that bigger is always better, is starting to break down. We're seeing it all around us - the rise of the independent worker, the tiny startup that can outmaneuver the giant corporation. The internet has democratized access to information and resources, and suddenly the advantage of scale isn't so clear-cut anymore. I mean, sure, there are still areas where economies of scale make sense - but we're seeing more and more examples where the agility and responsiveness of smaller organizations are allowing them to outcompete the giants. And that's what I'm trying to get at in this essay - that the game is changing, and we need to rethink our assumptions about what it takes to succeed.
How does the author think technology has distorted humanity's natural behavior, particularly in the context of work and lifestyles?

"I think technology has messed with our natural rhythms, you know? Our bodies were meant to move, not sit at a desk all day. And our brains were meant to focus on one thing at a time, not juggle a million tabs and notifications. It's like, we're built for hunting and gathering, not for staring at screens all day. And don't even get me started on the food thing - we're designed to eat berries and nuts, not Doritos and pizza. So, when you apply that same idea to work and lifestyles, you can see how we've drifted pretty far from our natural state. We're meant to be makers and doers, not just sit-arounders."
What inspired you to highlight the overwhelming importance of college entrance exams in South Korean culture?

I think what really got me was that parent's quote - "determine 70 to 80 percent of a person's future" - it's like, whoa, that's a heck of a lot of pressure. And it's not just some number, it's like, this is a parent saying this, someone who's lived it, who's seen their kid's whole life ride on this one exam. That's what really drove home for me the stakes involved here.
What inspired you to coin the term "ramen profitable" and what problem were you trying to solve by defining it?

I just got tired of people tossing around silly valuations and pretending like they're crushing it when in reality they're barely scraping by. I wanted to give a name to that precarious, hand-to-mouth existence that so many founders know all too well. It's not sexy, it's not exciting, but it's the reality for a lot of startups. And by defining it, I hoped to inject a dose of realism into the startup ecosystem. You can't be "ramen profitable" and still pretend you're the next Google. It's about being honest with yourself about where you are, and working from there.
What motivated you to reflect on your experience at Yahoo, and what do you hope readers take away from your introspection?

"I think what motivated me to reflect on my experience at Yahoo was just a sense of...I don't know, maybe disappointment? Disillusionment? We were supposed to be the next big thing, you know? And it just didn't work out that way. And I think I wanted to try to understand what went wrong, not just for myself, but for anyone who's ever been part of something that didn't quite live up to the hype. I hope readers take away that it's okay to admit when things don't work out, and that sometimes it's necessary to take a step back and try to figure out what went wrong. Because if you can't learn from your mistakes, you're never going to make progress."
What inspired the author to draw upon their childhood reading experience in this narrative?

I think it's because that story about Ooka Tadasuke has just stuck with me all these years. There's something about the idea of this poor student getting full just from the smell of food that really resonated with me, even as a kid. And as I grew older, I started to realize that it wasn't just a quirky little anecdote - it's actually a powerful commentary on the nature of poverty and class. I think drawing on that childhood memory allowed me to tap into those feelings of empathy and understanding that I had as a kid, and to explore them in a more nuanced way.
What drives your curiosity to immediately assess a startup's likelihood of achieving profitability when you first engage with them?

You want to know what drives my curiosity, huh? Well, let me tell you - it's because I've seen too many startups burning through cash like it's going out of style, without a care in the world about when they'll actually turn a profit. I mean, it's like they think the money fairy is just gonna magically appear and bail them out. Newsflash: that fairy doesn't exist. I want to know if they've got a realistic shot at making it to profitability because, let's be real, that's the only way they'll survive in the long run. And if they can't answer that question, then we've got a problem.
How did your perception of parenthood change after having kids, and what prompted that shift?

Parenthood, the great disruptor of one's life, forcing you to confront all your noble ideals and, actually live them. Before having kids, I thought I was afraid of losing my freedom, of being tied down, of, actually growing up. But what I was really afraid of was being responsible for tiny humans who would not only rely on me for survival but also look up to me as a role model. That's terrifying, right? What motivated you to share your thoughts and advice with students who reached out to you, despite feeling uncertain about being a reliable source of guidance?

What drives the author to believe that exceptional individuals significantly surpass their average counterparts in their respective fields?

What inspired you to challenge the common stereotype of nerds being inherently shy and introverted in social situations?

"I wanted to take a very abstract concept, like the struggles of starting a company, and make it tangible. I mean, who hasn't lifted something heavy at some point? It's a universal experience. And when you lift with your back, you're gonna hurt yourself. It's just common sense. But people do the same thing with their startups - they try to muscle through with their 'back', with their ego, with their willpower. And they end up getting crushed. So, I figured, why not use a metaphor that everyone can relate to? It makes the point more memorable, and it's just more fun to read."
What inspired you to focus on the initial perceived shortcomings of successful startups, rather than their eventual successes?

people always want to talk about the triumph, the glory, the IPOs and the accolades. But I'm more interested in the awkward teenage years, you know? The phase where these companies were still figuring things out, stumbling around in the dark, making mistakes left and right. That's where the real lessons are, if you ask me. The 'before' picture, not the 'after'. And let's be honest, who doesn't love an underdog story? I mean, Instagram was just a bunch of hipsters filtering their coffee cups, Facebook was just a college project, and Airbnb was just a couple of dudes renting out a friend's place on an air mattress. They all seemed pretty lame at first, but we know how that turned out. So, what's the magic there? What did they do right, despite looking so wrong? That's what I'm trying to get at.
What motivated you to consider the availability of a domain name as a crucial factor in a startup's naming decision?

it's just one of those no-brainers, right? I mean, think about it. Your company name is your brand identity, and your domain name is like the online equivalent of your company name. If you can't get the .com, you're basically asking for branding confusion. And let's be real, who wants to be "X.io" or "X.co" or whatever? It's like, come on, you're a startup, not some amateur hour operation. You gotta have the .com, or what's the point?
What inspired the author to highlight the role of social influence in investors' decision-making processes?

You see, I've always been fascinated by the absurdities of the startup ecosystem, and this whole "herd mentality" thing among investors is one of the most glaring ones. I mean, these are supposedly smart, savvy people, and yet they're allowing the opinions of others to sway their judgments like a bunch of schoolkids on a playground. It's like, come on, can't they think for themselves? But of course, that's not how it works. It's all about social proof, about seeing what others are doing and jumping on the bandwagon. And that's what I wanted to expose in this essay - how this phenomenon can lead to exponential growth, or, a massive bubble waiting to burst.
What assumption do you think most people make about the development of their beliefs, and how does this influence their confidence in those beliefs?

Yeah, most people seem to think that the more they're exposed to different experiences, the more validated their beliefs become. It's like, the more they survive these experiences, the more convinced they are that they're right. It's this idea that, if their beliefs haven't been disproven yet, they must be true, or at least, true enough. This way of thinking gives them a false sense of security, you know? They start to believe that their beliefs are increasingly infallible just because they've stuck around for a while. It's like, they're confusing persistence with proof.
What criteria do you think is most important when evaluating the "interestingness" of a startup founder?

Influence, hands down. I mean, you can't just look at someone's bank account or their features in the press. Anyone can get lucky or hire a good PR firm. I want to know, are they changing the way people think? Are they making me think differently about business, about life? When I'm talking to entrepreneurs, am I using them as an example, saying "hey, look at what they did"? That's what makes someone interesting, in my book.
What Sparked Kate Courteau's Interest in Joining YC's Team After Years of Only Hearing About It?

You want to know what finally got Kate Courteau to take the plunge, huh? Well, let me tell you, it was immersion, total immersion. She'd heard about YC for years, but it wasn't until she spent a serious chunk of time, nine months to be exact, really diving in and getting her hands dirty that she was hooked. The scales fell from her eyes, and she was like, "This is it, I'm in." That's what sparked her interest, the unvarnished truth of YC, warts and all.
What motivates the author to perceive social niceties, like saying "pleased to meet you," as harmless despite being insincere?

I think it's because, deep down, we all recognize that these little white lies are just a social lubricant, you know? They're a way to ease into interactions with people we don't know very well, to avoid awkwardness and tension. We're not trying to deceive anyone; we're just trying to be polite and friendly, even if we're not necessarily feeling it. And everyone understands that, so it's not like we're actually trying to pull the wool over anyone's eyes. It's just a way to make social interactions smoother, you know?
What role does the author believe a university plays in creating a Silicon Valley-like environment?

You want to know about universities, huh? Alright, let me tell you - a first-rate university is the foundation of a Silicon Valley-like environment. It's like the spark that sets the whole thing off. You get a bunch of smart people together, and suddenly you've got a hub of innovation and entrepreneurship. It's not just about the research and education, it's about creating a culture that fosters creativity and risk-taking. And trust me, rich people want to be around that energy, so they move in, and next thing you've got a Valley-like scene unfolding.
What motivated you to highlight the Edited versions of scientists' biographies, and what message did you hope to convey by doing so?

You see, I think we're guilty of putting our scientific heroes on pedestals, and in doing so, we sanitize their stories to the point where we lose sight of the uncertainty and the risk-taking that's inherently part of the scientific process. By highlighting the edited versions of scientists' biographies, I wanted to expose the fact that we're not getting the full story, that these legends of science weren't always right, and that their journey to discovery was often marked by missteps and false starts. My hope is that by conveying this more nuanced view, we can inspire a new generation of scientists and thinkers to be more willing to take risks, to experiment, and to challenge conventional wisdom.
What does the author admire most about Ron Conway, and how does this reflect their personal values?

Ron Conway, the man is a national treasure! What I admire most about him is that he's not only a brilliant investor, but a genuinely good guy. I mean, in an industry where people can be cutthroat and ruthless, Ronco stands out for his kindness and integrity. He's the embodiment of what's right in the Valley, and I think that's something to be celebrated. For me, personally, it's a breath of fresh air to see someone so successful being a good human being, you know? It reflects my own values of integrity, kindness, and doing the right thing, even when no one's looking. Ron Conway is the real deal, and that's what I admire most about him.
What motivates the author to suggest looking for problems as a way to generate startup ideas?

"Because, let's be honest, most startup ideas are crap. They're just some half-baked notion someone had in the shower, without any real understanding of the problem they're trying to solve. But, if you're looking to solve a problem that's been driving you nuts, well, that's a different story. That's when you'll create something that's actually valuable, because you're not just trying to make a quick buck, you're trying to solve a real problem that affects you, and likely, a whole bunch of other people too."
What inspired you to notice and highlight the trend of hardware startups in the batch, and what do you think this trend indicates about the startup ecosystem?

I've been doing this for a while, and you start to notice patterns. I've had a front-row seat to the startup world for over a decade now, and when I saw 7 out of 84 companies in our last batch focused on hardware, I knew something was up. It's not like I was actively looking for it, it just hit me - this is different. And it's not just the sheer number, it's the quality too. These weren't just hobbyist projects, these were serious companies tackling real problems. So, I asked myself, what's behind this? And what does it mean for the startup ecosystem as a whole? I think it indicates a shift. The rise of hardware startups, to me, signifies a maturation of the startup ecosystem. The easy software problems have been solved, and entrepreneurs are moving on to the harder, more complex problems - like hardware. It's a natural progression, but it's also a lot harder. You need more capital, more expertise, more time. But the potential payoff is huge. So, in short, I didn't so much "notice" the trend as it just slapped me in the face. And what it indicates is that we're entering a new phase of startup innovation, one that's more complex, more challenging, but ultimately, more rewarding.
What triggered your father's interest in mathematics, according to his own childhood narrative?

"Ah, when I was talking to him about his childhood, there's this clear watershed around age 12, when he suddenly got interested in math. He never really explained what sparked it, but it was like a switch was flipped and he knew what he wanted to do with his life. It's fascinating, really."
What inspired you to give a talk about turning Pittsburgh into a startup hub, especially considering its unique advantages?

"I've always been fascinated by the concept of startup hubs, and how certain cities seem to have this magical aura about them that attracts entrepreneurs and innovators. And I'm from Pittsburgh, so I had a personal stake in wanting to see my hometown thrive. But what really got me thinking was the paradox of Pittsburgh having all these great universities, a talented workforce, and a relatively low cost of living, yet still not being a major player in the startup world. It was like, we've got all the ingredients for a startup hub, what's missing? So, I started digging into what was holding us back, and what we could do to overcome those obstacles, and that's how this talk came about."
What led the author to conclude that the convergence of computers and TV would ultimately favor computers?

You see, I think it's because computers were always the ones doing the heavy lifting, even back then. TVs were just, well, dumb displays, whereas computers were the ones with the brains, the flexibility, the adaptability. It was only a matter of time before they swallowed up the TV's role and made it their own. I mean, think about it, what was the TV really bringing to the table? A screen? Please, computers had those too. Content? Ha! Computers could generate their own content, and then some. So, it was only a matter of time before the computer's superiority would shine through.

Well, it's funny, I'd been trying to distill this quality down for a while, and I was stuck on the opposite - "hapless". And then one day, it just clicked: relentlessly resourceful. It's not just about being clever or working hard, it's about being able to get things done no matter what obstacles are in your way. A good startup founder has to be able to MacGyver their way out of trouble, to find a way to make it work even when everything's going wrong. And that's what "relentlessly resourceful" means to me - it's a mindset, a way of attacking problems, a refusal to give up.
What motivates the author to suggest that startup ideas should emerge from personal needs or desires?

It's like, if you're scratching your own itch, you're more likely to make something that actually works, and that resonates with others who have the same problem. What does the author believe is the primary message that New York City conveys to its inhabitants?

What inspires you to share lessons learned from missed opportunities, as seen in your post about Airbnb, and how does this approach reflect your values as a Venture Capitalist?

What motivated you to highlight the counterintuitive nature of startup investing as the foundation of your essay?

I think people have this romanticized notion of startup investing, that it's all about throwing money at a bunch of shiny new ideas and waiting for the winners to emerge. But the reality is, it's a lot more nuanced than that. I wanted to shake people out of that complacent thinking, you know? Startup investing is a business, just like any other, and it requires a deep understanding of its own unique rhythms and contradictions. What motivated you to frame the debate between tech companies and anti-immigration groups in terms of a choice between importing foreign talent and training American programmers?

I wanted to get at the heart of this debate, which is really about the future of work in America. It's not just about H-1B visas or coding boot camps, it's about what kind of society we want to be. Do we want to be a country that's open to the best and brightest from around the world, or do we want to invest in our own people, to give them the skills they need to thrive in the 21st century? I mean, these tech companies, they're not just looking for programmers, they're looking for the easiest way to get the job done. And if that means bringing in someone from India or China, they'll do it. But that's not a solution, that's a Band-Aid. We need to be thinking about how we can create a workforce that's equipped to compete with the best in the world, not just import it from somewhere else.
What inspired the author to highlight the importance of being cautious when interacting with corporate development teams?

I've just seen too many founders get taken advantage of by these corp dev smooth-talkers. They roll in, all Cheshire cat smiles and "we're interested in exploring strategic opportunities," when what they're really doing is sizing you up for the kill. I wanted to give entrepreneurs a heads-up: don't get lulled into thinking these guys are your friends. They're just doing their job, and their job is to buy you out for as cheap as possible. So, I figured it was time someone whispered a warning in the ear of the startup community: beware the corp dev wolves in sheep's clothing.
What motivated the author to define a startup in terms of growth potential rather than other common characteristics?

I think a lot of people have a misconception about what a startup is. They think it's just a young company, or a tech company, or a company that's got venture funding. But I wanted to get at the essence of what makes a startup a startup. And what I realized was that it's not about any of those things, it's about growth potential. A startup is a company designed to grow fast. That's what sets it apart from other companies. I mean, a sandwich shop can be a small business, but it's not a startup. It's not designed to grow exponentially. But a company that's got a scalable business model, that's what I'm talking about. And I think that's where the excitement is, that's where the innovation is.
What led you to share your insight about startup founders retaining control of the board after a series A round through a personal anecdote?

I've just seen so many startups get taken advantage of by VCs who promise the world and then swoop in and take control. What motivated you to share a strategy that you knew had ultimately failed, and what do you hope readers take away from your honesty about its ineffectiveness?

What motivated you to initially delay angel investing despite your interest in it?
